name: Transaction
overview:
This class allows you interact with Cloud Datastore.

First, install @google-cloud/datastore with npm:

$ npm install --save @google-cloud/datastore

If you are running your app on Google Compute Engine, you won't need to worry about supplying connection configuration options to @google-cloud/datastoreâ€” we figure that out for you.

However, if you're running your app elsewhere, you will need to provide project details to authenticate API requests.

Google Cloud Platform

var datastore = require('@google-cloud/datastore')();

Elsewhere

var datastore = require('@google-cloud/datastore')({ projectId: 'grape-spaceship-123', keyFilename: '/path/to/keyfile.json' });

The full set of options which can be passed to @google-cloud/datastore are outlined in our Authentication guide.

methods.name: Transaction
methods.description: A transaction is a set of Datastore operations on one or more entities. Each transaction is guaranteed to be atomic, which means that transactions are never partially applied. Either all of the operations in the transaction are applied, or none of them are applied.

examples.code: var transaction = datastore.transaction();

methods.name: commit
methods.description:
Commit the remote transaction and finalize the current transaction instance.

If the commit request fails, we will automatically rollback the transaction.

examples.caption: If the callback is omitted, we'll return a Promise.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request. If the commit fails, we automatically try to rollback the transaction (see datastore/transaction#rollback).

methods.name: createQuery
methods.description: Create a query for the specified kind. See datastore/query for all of the available methods.

methods.name: delete
methods.description: Delete all entities identified with the specified key(s) in the current transaction.

methods.name: rollback
methods.description: Reverse a transaction remotely and finalize the current transaction instance.

examples.caption: If the callback is omitted, we'll return a Promise.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request.

methods.name: run
methods.description: Begin a remote transaction. In the callback provided, run your transactional commands.

examples.caption: If the callback is omitted, we'll return a Promise.

params.name: callback
params.description: • The function to execute within the context of a transaction.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request.

methods.name: save
methods.description:
Insert or update the specified object(s) in the current transaction. If a key is incomplete, its associated object is inserted and the original Key object is updated to contain the generated ID.

This method will determine the correct Datastore method to execute (upsert, insert, or update) by using the key(s) provided. For example, if you provide an incomplete key (one without an ID), the request will create a new entity and have its ID automatically assigned. If you provide a complete key, the entity will be updated with the data specified.

By default, all properties are indexed. To prevent a property from being included in all indexes, you must supply an entity's data property as an array. See below for an example.

examples.caption: Save a single entity. Notice that we are providing an incomplete key. After the transaction is committed, the Key object held by the key variable will be populated with a path containing its generated ID.
To specify an excludeFromIndexes value for a Datastore entity, pass in an array for the key's data. The above example would then look like:
Save multiple entities at once.

params.name: entities.data
params.description: • Data to save with the provided key. If you provide an array of objects, you must use the explicit syntax: name for the name of the property and value for its value. You may also specify an excludeFromIndexes property, set to true or false.

examples.code: var incompleteKey = datastore.key(['Company']);

examples.caption: The following call will create 100 new IDs from the Company kind, which exists under the default namespace.
examples.code: datastore.allocateIds(incompleteKey, 100, function(err, keys) {});

examples.caption: Or, if you're using a transaction object.

You may prefer to create IDs from a non-default namespace by providing an incomplete key with a namespace. Similar to the previous example, the call below will create 100 new IDs, but from the Company kind that exists under the "ns-test" namespace.
If the callback is omitted, we'll return a Promise.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request

methods.name: createReadStream
methods.description: Retrieve the entities as a readable object stream.

params.name: options
params.description: • Optional configuration. See datastore#get for a complete list of options.

exceptions.description: If at least one Key object is not provided.

methods.name: get
methods.description: Retrieve the entities identified with the specified key(s) in the current transaction. Get operations require a valid key to retrieve the key-identified entity from Datastore.

examples.caption: Get a single entity.
examples.code:
var key = datastore.key(['Company', 123]);

datastore.get(key, function(err, entity) {});

examples.caption: Or, if you're using a transaction object.
Get multiple entities at once with a callback.
Here's how you would update the value of an entity with the help of the save method.
If the callback is omitted, we'll return a Promise.

params.name: options.consistency
params.description: • Specify either strong or eventual. If not specified, default values are chosen by Datastore for the operation. Learn more about strong and eventual consistency here.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request

params.name: callback.entity
params.description: • The entity object(s) which match the provided keys.

exceptions.description: If at least one Key object is not provided.

methods.name: runQuery
methods.description:
Datastore allows you to query entities by kind, filter them by property filters, and sort them by a property name. Projection and pagination are also supported.

The query is run, and the results are returned as the second argument to your callback. A third argument may also exist, which is a query object that uses the end cursor from the previous query as the starting cursor for the next query. You can pass that object back to this method to see if more results exist.

examples.caption: Where you see transaction, assume this is the context that's relevant to your use, whether that be a Datastore or a Transaction object.
Or, if you're using a transaction object.
A keys-only query returns just the keys of the result entities instead of the entities themselves, at lower latency and cost.
If the callback is omitted, we'll return a Promise.

params.name: options.consistency
params.description: • Specify either strong or eventual. If not specified, default values are chosen by Datastore for the operation. Learn more about strong and eventual consistency here.

params.name: callback
params.description: • The callback function. If omitted, a readable stream instance is returned.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request

params.name: callback.info.endCursor
params.description: • Use this in a follow-up query to begin from where these results ended.

params.name: callback.info.moreResults
params.description:
• Datastore responds with one of:
    • datastore#MORE_RESULTS_AFTER_LIMIT: There may be more results after the specified limit.
    • datastore#MORE_RESULTS_AFTER_CURSOR: There may be more results after the specified end cursor.
    • datastore#NO_MORE_RESULTS: There are no more results.

methods.name: runQueryStream
methods.description:
Get a list of entities as a readable object stream.

See datastore#runQuery for a list of all available options.

examples.caption: If you anticipate many results, you can end a stream early to prevent unnecessary processing and API requests.
